IMVO is a Ukrainian company which focuses on manufacturing steel storage products. These may include cantilever racking, roller tables, mezzanine systems and drive-in systems as well.

Ukraine's leading manufacturer of specialist storage solutions

IMVO is a Ukrainian firm based in the city of Lviv, which manufactures specialist storage systems including racking, shelving, drive in storage systems and mezzanines. The company was founded in 1993, soon after Ukraine re-gained independence, and partnered with the nation's steel producers to roll out a range rolled steel products. The opening of a modern production facility followed in 1997, and IMVO enjoyed a period of international expansion, selling its rolled steel products to clients in Hungary, Slovakia, Bulgaria, Poland, Latvia and Lithuania. The company also became involved as a key supplier to several high profile energy pipeline projects, due to the quality of its rolled steel products.

However, IMVO made a significant change to its business in the early 2000s, when it chose to direct its energies towards the production of high quality storage systems. Initial projects included the installation of roller tables for local airports, and supplying Ukraine's growing warehousing sector, as well as a huge project to supply electronics-giant Samsung's Ukrainian operations. This created additional markets worldwide, with IMVO soon providing heavy duty storage systems to clients in Germany, Kazakhstan, Russia and Sweden. This growth has been underpinned by a corporate mission which prioritises research, staff skills and delivering customer satisfaction to IMVO's clients. This client support includes dispatching IMVO technicians to assess the needs of each customer, analysing their material flows and production techniques so that the right storage and order picking system can be installed. Using CAD techniques, the firm's staff then produce detailed plans of the proposed storage systems, and undertake to monitor the installation during the warranty period after the job is completed.

The IMVO product portfolio

The range of products manufactured by IMVO includes:

  • Selective pallet racking
  • Drive in/drive through storage
  • Mobile racks
  • Roller tables
  • Shelving
  • Cantilever, gravitation and combined racking
  • Mezzanines
  • Specialist steel storage structures

The products manufactured by IMVO are suitable for any organization that requires complex materials handling and storage systems. Warehouses and factories that deal in small components and stocks of fragile materials are common clients, as are transport and health care bodies such as airports and hospitals.

HIMOINSA is a manufacturer of  electricity generation and lighting technology. The firm specializes in manufacturing robust, reliable generators that are used in remote power generation and engineering projects.

A Spanish Manufacturer of Mobile and Static Power Generators & Lights

HIMOINSA SL manufactures power generators and mobile lighting sources for business and private applications. Based in the Murcia region of Spain, HIMOINSA Spain was founded in 1982 and specializes in the generation of clean, renewable and mobile energy. The firm now operates across five continents in more than one hundred countries, operating 8 manufacturing plants and running 10 subsidiary companies across the world. Its factories are located in countries as diverse as the United States, France, Brazil, India and China, but the company can market its energy generation equipment to all countries on all continents via strategically placed sales subsidiaries in countries such as Panama, Dubai and Angola. HIMOINSA see their strategy as based around a future demand for sustainable, renewable energy, and the firm has been working hard to enter the African market, where decentralized energy solutions are welcomed by governments and businesses.

Website: himoinsa.com

Organizing in-house component manufacturing to respond to customer demand

The firm also specializes in what it calls "vertical production." This refers to the fact the HIMOINSA manufactures all of the components for its generation sets in-house, and can be extremely responsive the needs of clients as a result. The firm has also embraced automation at all of its plants, with generators being manufactured via state of the art  robotics and durable welding techniques, which provide its products with a long life time. This durability is backed up by durability analysis carried out with the firm's own software. HIMOINSA has also incorporated technologies like passivation, which prevents corrosion via specially formulated protective coatings, and the firm has also sought to make its products as customer-friendly as possible via innovations like multi-language control consoles. These consoles can also be easily synchronised with other HIMOINSA generators, to provide integrated lighting and electricity generation in demanding conditions. This technology has enabled the company to participate in many flagship projects, such as Tibet Airport, the Panama Subway and power plant construction in Angola.

The range of generation and lighting products manufactured by HIMOINSA includes:

  • Heavy electricity generators (670 to 2700 kVA)
  • Industrial electricity generators (4 to 755 kVA)
  • HR range of generators (17 to 2500 kVA)
  • Portable electricity generators (3 to 10 kVA)
  • Apolo Start robust lighting towers
  • Apolo Compact small lighting towers
  • Apolo Box mobile lighting towers
  • Kit tower lighting centres (without a generator)
  • Integrated power plant solutions
  • Cogeneration technology

HIMOINSA products are used in both static power plants as back up systems, and in engineering projects where mobile power generation is essential, such as underground tunnelling and remote infrastructure construction. Their lighting may also be used at leisure events and by mobile units such as film crews. Their cogeneration technology could be used by factories where energy efficiency is a priority.

WESTWOOD is a British company that makes a wide range of  garden tractors designed to provide the perfect finish to a lawn of any size, from a small domestic garden to areas of three acres and more. From a factory outside Oxford, England, the company has built a reputation for its high quality range of products.

Website: westwoodtractors.com

History of WESTWOOD Tractors

WESTWOOD has been producing its distinctive red garden tractors for more than thirty years aimed at keen gardeners, both amateur and professional, who want the very best finish for their lawns. The WESTWOOD Tractors brand is part of Countax Ltd, which also produces garden tractors under its own brand. At the WESTWOOD factory just outside Oxford that it shares with the Countax-branded products, the company employs some 130 people and WESTWOOD Tractors says that the key to its success over three decades is that its team of engineers listens to what customers want. WESTWOOD says that a programme of constant innovation has resulted in electronic controls that are waterproofed. Under factory conditions, painted parts have been exposed to some 500 hours of salt spray without corrosion, allowing WESTWOOD garden tractors to operate in all weathers. In 2010, the WESTWOOD parent company, Countax Ltd, was bought by the large American company Ariens of Wisconsin, which produces a wide range of outdoor power equipment under its own name, and employs some 1,200 people worldwide. Like Countax, and its WESTWOOD brand, Ariens is privately owned, by the same family that began the firm in 1933. Ariens says that under its ownership, WESTWOOD will continue to expand its range, drawing on its reputation and existing customer base. There are plans for further market expansion both in the United Kingdom, which remains the main WESTWOOD Tractors market, and across the rest of Europe.

The WESTWOOD Tractors Product Portfolio

The range of commercial and industrial products manufactured by JEEP includes:

  • T Series garden tractor
  • F Series 4TRAC garden tractor
  • V Series garden tractor
  • Powered scarifier
  • Powered grass collector
  • Powered broadcast spreader
  • Snowblade
  • Chevron Tyres

WESTWOOD garden tractors are a range of high quality riding on lawnmowers to suit varying sizes of lawn, some with four-wheel drive, and all manufactured in England. Westwood tractors also produces a wide range of accessories designed to extend the abilities and to protect their garden tractors.

The American firm JEEP is a manufacturer of SUVs and utility vehicles with a famous history of producing rugged off-road vehicles. The firm is owned by Chrysler, which in turn is owned by Italy's Fiat, and has an international client base.

Gaining fame as a workhorse during wartime, and an off-road legend

JEEP is an internationally known American manufacturer of rugged off-road and SUV vehicles, which also manufactures a range of commercial vehicles. First produced in 1941, JEEP's are the oldest off-road vehicles still in production, and gained fame for their association with the American army during World War Two and beyond. After the war, JEEP focused on manufacturing off road vehicles for commercial and private applications, including technologically advanced models which had the capability to traverse river beds. This kind of rugged quality made them popular as business vehicles for companies working in hard to access terrain such as mining firms, quarries, oil and gas exploration and agricultural businesses. During the 1950s, JEEP also began to produce 4-wheel drive trucks, delivery vans that were used by the US Post Office, while later decades saw models like the Dispatcher, which became a commonly used vehicle in emergency services and policing organizations.

Expanding production across the world and focusing on SUV models

During the 1990s, JEEP began to move away from its focus on all-terrain working vehicles, producing a more commercial selection of SUVs that have been popular with urban taxi firms and as company cars. But the Wrangler model of JEEPs continued to feature high performance 4-wheel drive technologies and continue to be used by businesses that operate in challenging environments. One of the features of JEEP's history has been that the firm has licensed its designs to be manufactured across the world, helping it to become a global brand. Factories in countries as far apart as Argentina, China, the Philippines, Israel and Venezuela have all acquired JEEP factories and produced some of the firm's models. Nowadays, the company continues to offer commercial vehicles as part of its product range. This includes the Grand Cherokee range of SUVs, which features a V8 engine and enhanced safety features, as well as the Wrangler selection of off-road vehicles. SUVs like the Liberty and the Patriot are also marketed as business vehicles for cab companies and small businesses.

The JEEP product portfolio

The range of commercial and industrial vehicles manufactured by JEEP includes:

  • Grand Cherokee utility vehicles
  • Wrangler 4-wheel drive vehicles
  • Patriot and Liberty SUVs
  • Second Hand 4-wheel drive off-road JEEP vehicles and Dispatcher vans

The vehicles manufactured by JEEP are mainly used as personal vehicles or as commercial business vehicles. Some of their models are appropriate for use as taxi cabs and courtesy cars, while the Wrangler continues to offer a high performance off-road option for farmers, ranchers and other businesses operating in challenging terrain.

Italian firm IVECO manufactures trucks, vans, defence vehicles, fire-fighting vehicles and other industrial vehicles. Through strategic acquisitions and research, the firm has developed a wide variety of products targeted at many economic sectors.

One of the world's leading industrial vehicle manufacturers

IVECO S.p.A. (Industrial Vehicles Corporation) is a leading Italian manufacturer of trucks and other industrial vehicles. The company was formed in 1975 from the merger of five separate firms - Fiat Industrial Vehicles, OM, Lancia Special Vehicles, Unic and Magirus-Deutz. This brought together vehicle manufacturing expertise from across Europe into one consolidated industrial organization, allowing IVECO to expand across the world. The merger also allowed IVECO to launch with a huge range of vehicles on offer. By 1979, the product range included 200 models, from light vehicles to heavy trucks. Some of these, including the instantly popular Daily range of light vans, were introduced in the years after IVECO's formation, as the brand began to generate a reputation for ease of use and reliability. This was enhanced during the 1980s, when IVECO adopted a strategy of boosting its international image via sporting sponsorship (and was one of the first major companies to do so).

Expanding into fire-fighting and passenger transport vehicles

Innovation also continued, with the introduction of the world's first direct injection light diesel engine in 1985. The firm also moved into other industrial areas with the acquisition of Astra in 1986, which manufactured dump trucks and loaders for use by mining and construction firms. The 1990s saw IVECO focus on its range of haulage vehicles, which became a common sight on European roads. The firm's trucks gained international recognition with the Euro Cargo and Euro Tech models being names Truck of the Year in 1992 and 1993. International growth continued, with the acquisition of Seddon Atkinson's range of refuse collection vehicles, and a Chinese venture with Yuejin Motor Company to manufacture fire-fighting vehicles. The late 90s and 2000s saw IVECO continue to expand, with its buses section growing particularly rapidly, as well as its powertrain manufacturing concern. And brand expansion also continued, with a high-profile sponsorship of the 2006 Winter Olympics in Turin and sponsorship of Ferrari's F1 racing team. The firm also moved into ecologically friendly design, with Eco Bus models coming onto the market and more awards, with the Stralis Hi-Way scooping the Truck of the Year award in 2012.

The IVECO product portfolio

The range of vehicles manufactured by IVECO includes:

  • Magirus fire fighting vehicles
  • Astra mining and construction vehicles
  • Defence vehicles
  • Passenger transport vehicles
  • Haulage trucks
  • Medium and light vans (natural gas, hybrid and electric tractions available)

The vehicles manufactured by IVECO have found a variety of uses. The Magirus range are widely used in fire fighting, while IVECO has a large portion of the defence vehicles market, and their trucks are a popular choice among haulage firms. Their buses are also popular with municipal authorities and private coach firms.

HOLZ-HER is one of the leading German machining companies, which manufactures edge banders, CNC machining centres, pressure band saws and panel saws, primarily for woodworking companies.

A leading German manufacturer of machining centres

HOLZ-HER GmbH is a German firm which manufactures machine tools such as edge banders, CNC machining centres and panel saws. The firm was founded in the Black Forest region of Germany in 1914 by Karl Matthias Reich, and at first specialized in the production of wire and wire-based products. During the 1920s, HOLZHER started to produce machining centres for the woodworking industry, and introduced its first electric machining centre in 1936 with the marketing of a hand-held circular saw. During the post-war period, HOLZHER achieved worldwide recognition for its feeding systems for machining centres, making complex machining tasks easier to achieve and safer for operators. 1958 saw the firm make a significant leap, with the introduction of its first vertical panel saw, which swiftly became one of its signature products.

International expansion and constant investment in innovation

While the 1960s and 70s found HOLZHER focusing on stationary woodworking machinery such as advanced edge banders, the 80s saw rapid global expansion. HOLZ-HER Germany was also spun off from its parent company under the name Reich Special Machines GmbH, and employed over 350 staff around the world by 1997, yet was still owned by the Reich family, as it had been since 1914. During the late 1990s and 2000s, HOLZHER subsidiaries were formed in Singapore, Spain, Italy and Switzerland, and a plant in Austria was extended with a huge manufacturing space, training centre and servicing facility all on one site. Technical innovations followed this new expansion, with the introduction of revolutionary new glue application systems and pressure bar saws. By 2007, HOLZHER CNC Technology has introduced a cutting edge 5-axis CNC machining centre, and was regularly being recognised by industry awards for its advanced designs and high quality machining products. The modern HOLZ-HER GmbH organization involves close attention to customer experiences, and the firm operates an extensive spare parts delivery service from its headquarters in Nürtingen, as well as a fully trained and easy to access customer support telephone line.

 

Website: holzer.com

The HOLZ-HER product portfolio

The range of machining products manufactured by HOLZHER includes:

  • Edge banders
  • CNC machining centres (3 and 5 axis models)
  • Pressure band saws
  • Vertical panel saws
  • CNC machining software and training packages

The product manufactured by HOLZHER are used by companies and other organizations that require advanced machining centres. This may include woodworking companies such as cabinet and bed-makers, window manufacturers and house-builders, but the firm's machinery can be used with other materials as well.

HSM is a German company which specializes in the manufacturing of document shredders and waste balers for administrative clients and companies with high volume waste flows.

From a small workshop to being a leading shredder and baler manufacturer

HSM GmbH & Co. KG is a firm which manufactures document shredding and paper waste management machinery for organizations that carry out a large volume of sensitive administrative tasks as well as industrial concerns. The firm was founded as Hermann Schwelling Maschinenbau GmbH in the German town of Salem in 1971, and began by manufacturing baling presses to be used with large volumes of cardboard. From humble beginnings in Schwelling's workshop, HSM has expanded to occupy large manufacturing facilities where the firm manufactures baling presses which can deliver a pressing force of 150 tonnes. The company's pressing equipment has also been developed to deal with a wide variety of materials including paper, cardboard, plastics, car tyres and foil, assisting with waste disposal and recycling efforts. HSM operates three manufacturing plants in Germany, in the towns of Salem, Reichenbach and Frickingen, as well as a joint venture in China which manufactures low-cost document shredders.

Becoming an international supplier of waste management equipment

In addition to its core manufacturing operations, HSM also operates a wide network of international subsidiaries in countries such as the United Kingdom, United States, Poland and France, allowing it to reach customers across Europe and North America. The company has also made agreements with distributors to act as sales and service nodes in over 100 countries, providing HSM with a broad access to new and existing clients. The firm has a 700 strong workforce spread across the world, and relies heavily on exports, which make up 70 percent of HSM's sales. The company has also benefited from the trend towards environmental technology, with sustainable products now constituting 45 percent of the firm's sales, a slice that is continuing to grow. This growth is complemented by HSM's focus on staff and client training. The company has set up an online and face to face academy which provides seminar style training on data protection and how to operate and service HSM products. The company also offers bespoke consultancy regarding waste management solutions for clients with complex waste flows.

The HSM product portfolio

The range of waste management products manufactured by HSM includes:

  • Document shredders
  • Hard drive shredders
  • Guillotines
  • Rotary trimmers
  • Stack cutters
  • Baling presses (vertical, horizontal, channel, dewatering and barrel)
  • Shredder baler combinations
  • Cardboard perforators
  • Plastic bottle compaction and recycling machinery

The product range manufactured by HSM is used widely by office organizations and health care bodies which deal with large amounts of paper-based confidential documents. Their balers and presses are used by factories and warehouses that deal with high volumes of cardboard and paper packaging, and their compactors are used by public bodies in recycling strategies.

The Japanese firm HONDA is a multi-national corporation which specializes in the manufacture of advanced engines for commercial and industrial vehicles, power tools and aircraft. The firm has a strong focus on innovation and research, and is recognised as one of the "greenest" large companies in operation.

One of the leading manufacturers of vehicles and power tools

The Japanese firm HONDA (also known as HONDA Giken Kogyo Kabushiki-gaishai) is a well-known manufacturer of commercial and industrial vehicles, but also manufactures equipment as diverse as mowers, outboard motors and snowblowers for commercial customers. The firm was founded by engineer Soichiro HONDA in 1937 as a supplier of piston rings to Toyota Corporation but quickly became known for manufacturing engines for motorized bicycles. HONDA became one of Japan's largest motorcycle makers during the 1950s and 60s but also started to produce commercial vehicles such as pick-up trucks during the same period. At the same time, HONDA also chose to use its expertise in engine production to manufacture high quality commercial tools such as blowers, mowers, tillers and inflatable boats. This was such a success, that by 2007 the firm was selling some 6 million units worldwide every year, and had established a market-leading position in sectors such as medium range outboard motors.

From light vans to trucks, aircraft and power tools

In the 1990s and 2000s, the company expanded its research and development facilities, becoming one of the world's great corporate research centres in areas such as hybrid vehicle engines and robotics. The firm began to introduce versions of its cars, vans and motorcycles which could deliver far greater fuel efficiency due to advanced hybrid engines, and still markets the only compressed natural gas vehicle that has been licensed in the United States. HONDA has also been in the vanguard of marketing assembly-line produced fuel cell vehicles, a sign of its continuing commitment to following environmentally sustainable principles. Since 2004, the company has also expanded into new areas of advanced technology, developing new powertrain and aircraft models (and opening a HondaJet subsidiary in the United States) and driving down to price of hybrid engines, encouraging businesses to act more sustainably.

The HONDA product portfolio

The range of tools and commercial and industrial vehicles manufactured by HONDA includes:

  • Odyssey Minivans
  • Pilot SUVs
  • Ridgeline trucks
  • All terrain vehicles
  • HondaJet private aircraft
  • Portable electricity generators
  • Lawn mowers
  • Pumps
  • Snow blowers
  • Tillers
  • Trimmers
  • Multi-purpose utility vehicles
  • Outboard motors

The range of products manufactured by Honda could have many different applications. The firms trucks and vans are popular commercial vehicles, while their all-terrain and utility vehicles are used by militaries and mining companies and their power tools are used by industrial workshops, construction and land management firms.

CARNITECH: Fish and Seafood Processing Machinery and Equipment

CARNITECH manufacturers and supplies a wide range of fish and seafood processing equipment that includes filleting, head removal and pin-boning equipment. CARNITECH specialises in producing equipment for cutting,  grinding, sawing and slicing seafood.

A World Class Processor

CARNITECH was established in Stoving, Jutland, Denmark, in 1981. The founders designed and installed shrimp processing equipment for fishing trawlers and eventually became international suppliers of seafood processing equipment and systems. CARNITECH is a leader in the salmon processing industry with its precision devices for de-boning and salmon back-bone scraping. CARNITECH has recently amalgamated with Marel who were initially a meat and poultry grinding and forming machine and systems manufacturer. CARNITECH machines are used extensively in the UK and service of the processors are guaranteed through a wide network of technicians.

CARNITECH is now part of the Marel Group. Together the CARNITECH/MAREL partnership continue to develop cutting-edge food processing systems and have recently developed systems for handling vegetables, fruit and cheese. CARNITECH continually develops poultry processing systems and equipment, meat processing proceedures fish processing systems and equipment. CARNITECH is an innovative designer and producer of food processing technology. Their machinery and equipment is revolutionary and has accumulated recognition around the world.

Service is efficient and reliable. All parts are manufactured to give premier performance and are original parts giving correct application.

PANASONIC is one of the world leaders in innovative, high quality electrical and electronic goods, and the company is known for its exceptional range of audio-visial equipment and superior quality appliances.

One Man's Vision

PANASONIC founder Konosuke Matsushita founded his Matsushita Electric Housewares Manufacturing Works company with his wife and brother in law (future founder of Sanyo, Toshio Iue) in 1917 in Osaka, Japan. By 1922 he had opened a head office and his first factory, and by 1927 a range of bicycle lamps was selling over 30,000 units per month in its first year of production. Tetsujiro Nakao was placed in charge of the electrical heater division and developed exciting new products like the Super Electric Iron, which was better than competitors products and 30% lower in price. Tetsujiro would guide and influence the company's Research & Development for many years to come. As success continued, Matsushita renamed the company 'National' with a vision of his electrical goods in every home in Japan.

The creation of a global brand

In 1929, the Japanese economy was in crisis, but the company was flourishing. The company announced that it would develop in an upstanding manner, contributing to society as a whole. The PANASONIC philosophy is relatively unchanged to this day. By 1930, Matsushita had set up Kokudo Electric Co. to manufacture the company's first radios. Despite World War II and the hardships of the post-war years, PANASONIC grew and developed. In 1952 PANASONIC marketed their first black and white TV, and their first colour TV was made in 1960. Other notable landmarks include their first microwave oven in 1966, first CD player in 1982, their first notebook PC in 1990 and their first DVD player and Plasma TV in 1996. Now a global concern, PANASONIC continue to lead the way, developing products that combine exceptional functionality with high quality, and in keeping with the vision and philosophy of founder Konosuke Matsushita.

Some of the exciting products PANASONIC produce include :

  • Digital AV
  • Mobile phones
  • Home Appliances & Batteries
  • Beauty & Healthcare
  • Car AV & Navigation System

Werner REIS GmbH is known all around Germany as a reliable supplier of high-precision machine tool components. The application of innovative tools and an enormous capacity of the machine tools provide the company with the means to efficiently process materials of difficult machinability, such as stainless steel and high-grade steel.

The history of the company Werner REIS GmbH

The coded welder Werner Reis founded the welding company in 1961 with an initial manufacturing area of 250 m² (2,691 ft²). In 1970, the company moved to the industrial area Getmold and increased its manufacturing area to 600 m² (6,458 ft²). The department of mechanical engineering was established within the company REIS in 1975 and led to the Werner REIS Maschinenbau GmbH in 1985. The construction of the REIS plant in the year 2000 increased the manufacturing area to 3,500 m² (37,674 ft²) and the expansion of plant II further increased it to 4,400 m² (47,361 ft²). Between 2002 and 2010 it was possible for the company to put several portal milling machines into operation and REIS invests since its early beginnings continuously into state-of-the-art production technology. The networking of modern CAD/CAM tools with highly efficient CNC machines as well as progressive machining tools is constantly streamlined and purposefully optimized.

Job shop and batch production in a state-of-the-art machine park

Werner REIS Maschinenbau GmbH is specialized in the manufacture of components and small-scale series. The range of production includes:

  • Machine beds for the machine tool industry
  • Paper and woodworking machines
  • Test stations and appliances for the automotive and aerospace industry 

The company is equipped with a state-of-the-art machine park. All machine tools are CNC controlled and are equipped with a tool changer and universal milling heads that can be positioned through CNC technology. This makes the entire workpiece accessible to the technology and even the most complicated processing steps can be successfully finished. The department for steel constructions also produces weldments with up to 45,000 kg (99,200 lbs) per piece.

MONDINI is an Italian based company, which has great expertise in producing high quality food processing equipment. The company's spare parts, products and services are used by hypermarkets and manufacturers all over the globe.

Global leader in high quality food processing equipment

MONDINI's history really began when Mr. Giovanni Mondini assisted Findus in setting up their very first automated line for making frozen cannelloni and lasagne. This was in 1968. Two years later, Mr. Giovanni Mondini set up his own company, G. MONDINI SpA, which is popularly known as MONDINI. Since then, this family-owned business has expanded over the decades to be one of the global leaders for food processing equipment. With its key base in Cologne, a town east of Milan in Italy, MONDINI caters to various sectors such as medical, fish, red meat, sliced meat, ready meals and soft fruits. The 1970s saw the company's evolution in the catering and food service sectors. Efficient packing and better format of ready meals were the key focus of the 1980s. Then came the 1990s and emphasis on sealing and feed technology for best machine output. The key to MONDINI's success is innovation - providing the food and beverage industry with future proof multi format packaging solutions, which include MAP, tray skin and protruding skin. Solutions that offer features like additional shelf life, better presentation and easy peeling have made MONDINI stand out as one of the world's foremost leaders in high quality food processing equipment.

MONDINI's top products

  • Trave Multi Format Machine 1000
  • Trave Multi Format Machine 590XL
  • Trave Multi Format Machine 4X
  • Evo Multi Format Machine 367
  • Evo Multi Format Machine 367S
  • SF Machine - Heat Seal Only 90
  • SF Machine - Heat Seal Only 120X
  • De-Nesters - Auto Loading

The MONDINI product portfolio

The range of products that are manufactured by MONDINI includes:

  • Tray sealers
  • Automation

MONDINI's spare parts and products are used in sectors like baby food, cheese and dairy, medical, biscuits and snacks, ready meals, poultry, soft fruit, pet food, bakery and sandwiches, fresh produce and beverage sectors. Apart from spare parts and products, MONDINI also offers its expert service in maintaining or troubleshooting its machines. Partners include food and beverage manufacturers and hypermarkets.

OPTIMUM is a German company who has been manufacturing industrial machines since the early 1990s and remain at the forefront of technical innovation.

Website: optimum-machines.com

Information about the company

OPTIMUM Maschinen Germany GmbH has a rich heritage and has been passionate about manufacturing metalworking machines for around 20 years. The company founders are themselves machinists and possess a detailed knowledge of what is required in the metalworks industry. For two decades, they have designed and manufactured hundreds of innovative metalwork products consisting of meaningful and differentiated features. OPTIMUM have been one of the European market leaders in this industry for some time now and have built a firm reputation for quality, sustainability, accuracy and consistent value for money. Every member of this workforce from the CEO's to the people on the ground floor possesses a comprehensive knowledge of the machinist industry and that has allowed this company to develop some of the most trusted products in the metalworking community. All products created by OPTIMUM GmbH are developed to extremely demanding standards and they are manufactured in the same factory in which their inception takes place. All components of these innovative products are chosen after much deliberation, which ensures only the best designs, materials and production methods are utilized.

OPTIMUM Products

Since being founded in the early 1990s, OPTIMUM have been responsible for the inception of hundreds of metalworking products, including OPTIMUM lathes, milling machines and other machine tools. which are highly recommended by numerous enterprises today. NIKON is a Japanese based company, which is one of the world's foremost manufacturers of imaging and optical products. NIKON's products are broadly used in photography, bioscience, research, outdoor fieldwork and various industries especially semiconductor industry.

Global leader in the field of imaging and optical technology

With headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, NIKON is a global leader in the field of imaging and optical technology. The merging of three leading Japanese optical manufacturers in July, 1917 formed a solid background for Nippon Kogaku K.K, abbreviated Nikko, which means sunlight. The company started to shine with the introduction of Nikkor camera lens in 1932. A combination of old-fashioned craftsmanship and modern engineering technology, this lens took the world by storm. Photographers all over the globe fell in love with the Nikkor lens, symbolising the spirit of NIKON. Small compact cameras with the brand name NIKON made its debut in 1946. And with the introduction of NIKON F 35mm SLR or single-lens reflex cameras in 1959, NIKON changed the world. SLR cameras became a hit with photographers, both professionals and amateurs alike. These cameras were even used in the US space programs. The year 1988 saw the change of corporate name from Nippon Kogaku K.K to NIKON Corporation or NIKON for short. NIKON is the world's sole camera manufacturer that has processes starting from the very basic, glass manufacturing right up to the end product.

  • Imaging products such as film or digital cameras, lens and accessories
  • Sport optics such as laser rangefinders, binoculars and telescopes
  • Instrument products like measuring instruments and microscopes
  • Ophthalmic lens

The products made by NIKON are utilised in different kinds of environments. Partners include researchers, manufacturers, individuals, outdoor field experts, photographers, environmentalists and nature lovers.

LAYHER has been a pioneer of scaffolding systems for more than 65 years and has been one of the leading effort in the development of products used in this industry.

History of the LAYHER Ltd.

Founded in 1945, LAYHER began life as a relatively small enterprise and three years later, were manufacturing scaffolding ladders. This German manufacturer started out in Frankfurt and by the early 1950s, had branches in cities such as Nuremberg, Dusseldorf and Hamburg. Tubular steel ladders were a frequent output of this company by 1953 and four years later, LAYHER had stumbled across a revolution as they had begun to produce the world's first rolling towers. In short, they were mobile scaffolds which featured screwless joints, something which entered this industry with immense popularity. LAYHER's dedication to improved safety was obvious by the mid 1960s during the release of the SpeedyScaf. The steel and aluminium frame revolutionised the scaffolding market and because these products were far easier to assemble and dismantle, they were adopted by numerous empires with great enthusiasm. All-round scaffolding was one of the leading products of the 1970s and by the mid 1980, the cassette roof systems were providing incredible amounts of protection against environmental forces and hectic weather conditions. Dozens of other innovative products have been manufactured over the following decades and 2013 saw the release of the LAYHER Ltd. Lightweight, a high tensile Speedyscaf creating a new dimension in scaffolding. This family owned company has always focused on tomorrow and constantly strives to bring the world groundbreaking products. With over 1500 employees worldwide, LAYHER uk are one of the most trusted scaffolding brands across the globe.

LAYHER Product Portfolio

Although several of LAYHER's products have been mentioned in the brand history due to their importance in the course of scaffold development, more are listed below.

  • Stalu deck, lightweight aluminium
  • Lightweight cassette roof
  • Keder roof system
  • Keder roof XL
  • Dust proof protect system

BIZERBA GmbH is a German company, specialising in food processing equipment. This company has led the way with innovative technology and contributions worldwide, since 1866.

A straight way to innovation 

BIZERBA was founded by the Bizer brothers in 1866. They used their surname and the name of city Balingen, where their headquarters was located, for the company's name. In 1839 the Bizer Brothers received their first commission, to build a weighbridge for Balingen. BIZERBA went on to produce innovative equipment that would help to make slicing, processing, weighing, cashing and the checking of groceries more efficient.

In 1868 Andreas Bizer registered A. Bizer, Manufacturer of Weighbridges, as a small company. Andreas Bizer's son in law, Whilhelm Kraut, the then manager of the company, collaborated with master craftsmen Schlaich and Hauser, to create the world's very first pendulum quadrant weighing scales, in 1924. The scales were patented in 1930 by BIZERBA GmbH. Ever innovative, BIZERBA went on to design and produce the world's first industrial scale. The company brought its expertise to retail and grocery stores in 1965, with electronic measuring weights and pricing equipment. In 2002 BIZERBA were again the first to introduce CE glass touch screen scales. This revolutionised updating and scale management. Optical Article Recognition Scales were introduced in 2007 and in 2010 BIZERBA produced a new Ceraclean surface to their existing BIZERBA slicers.

BIZERBA Product Portfolio

  • Slicers
  • Retail scales
  • Meat processing machines
  • Industrial weighing systems
  • Labeller
  • Labels & Consumables
  • Software

BIZERBA design and produce a range of food processing and handling equipment, like Slicers, Meat Processing Machines, Retail Scales and Industrial Weighing Systems. They also create Labellers and a range of software, while providing an impeccable service. BIZERBA equipment remains on the cutting edge of technology and the company is currently represented in 120 countries worldwide. They supply a wide range of prominent grocery chain stores, such as Morrison's, in the UK and the Mexican chain store Soriana.

WEEKE Bohrsysteme GmbH is a German firm which manufactures wood processing machinery. The firm was founded by Gustav Weeke in 1945 in the Westphalian town of Herzebrock - a region with a large concentration of wood working factories. In the post-war decades WEEKE GmbH prospered, supplying machinery to such factories and expanding its operations. It also innovated, introducing significant advances into wood working processes, such as producing the first lock insertion machine and through-feed drilling - both of which have become standard in modern wood processing. The WEEKE family sold the firm in 1986, as it was included in the Homag group, although WEEKE Bohrsysteme GmbH retained its own identity and function, even adding sanding technology to its repertoire with the acquisition of Butfering in 2012. A history of TAKEUCHI Manufacturing

TAKEUCHI was established in the 1960s by Akio TAKEUCHI and in the early 1970s it introduced the first tracked excavator. By the end of the decade, TAKEUCHI had become so successful that it had established its second factory in Murakami, Japan. In the 1980s, TAKEUCHI introduced a whole host of new products as its business took off, among them the first rubber-tracked excavator. A few years later, TAKEUCHI Mfg introduced its eight ton class mini excavator into the United States, followed by its tracked excavator. These were the first compact excavators in the US, and set the stage for a period of growth in this market. The US remains a country where TAKEUCHI retains a significant presence. The 1990s brought further innovation, by introducing the first hydraulic extended tracks and a research and development facility was opened in Nagano. Over the next few years, TAKEUCHI opened operations in both the United Kingdom and, later, France, as the popularity of its products grew. The Finnish-Swedish firm VALTRA manufactures reliable tractors and other agricultural equipment. It has bases in both Europe and Latin America, as well as a global sales reach.

A leading Nordic tractor manufacturer with over a century of experience

VALTRA Inc. is a tractor manufacturing and servicing company with its origins in both Finland and Sweden. The firm began in Finland, when Valmet was formed in the nineteenth century. More recently, Valmet merged with Volvo Tractors to form a Swedish-Finnish combination named VALTRA, which distributes its tractors across the world. VALTRA was one of the pioneers of mechanical tractors, manufacturing its first combustion-engine powered agricultural vehicle back in 1913. Nowadays, the firm operates around a set of core principles, which include aspects like team play, openness and reliability. The firm has also developed a code of conduct regarding sustainability, installing facilities such as a waste wood burner at its factory and reducing waste products in general. VALTRA operates globally, selling its products in 75 countries. It has factories in the Finnish town of Suolahti, as well as the Brazilian town of Mogi das Cruzes which provides it with effective reach into the Latin American agricultural sector. VALTRA also has around 2100 employees across the world, and manufactures 24,000 tractors every year, each of them tailored to the specifications of clients. This focus on customer needs is one of the company's core practices, as well as a focus on "Nordic" reliability.

A history of SCM Group

SCM Group SpA traces its roots to the Italian city of Rimini in 1935 when Lanfranco Aureli and Nicola Gemmani started a company to make ploughs. At the end of the Second World War, they recognised a fall in the demand for agricultural machinery, but a rise in the need for window and door frames, as well as furniture as post-war reconstruction began. They combined their resources with an engineer called Giuseppe Gemmani and produced their first cast iron multi-purpose woodworking machine, known as L'invincibile B4. It was the beginning of SCM Group as it is known today. In 1954, the company devoted itself to providing woodworking equipment and rapid expansion followed. The first auomatic tetoning machine was produced in the 1960s. Branches were opened in the USA and France, among others. Rapid acquisition of other companies began in the 1980s, allowing the SCM Group to add the processing of plastic, glass, metals, stone and composite materials to its well-established woodworking machinery portfolio. From house building machinery to equipment for mass-producintg chairs, the SCM CNC Machinery has invested millions of euros in ensuring that its products are, the company believes, the best in the market, worldwide.

STILL forklifts is a large German company that manufactures a wide range of high quality industrial trucks, designed for various functions and powered by a range of innovative drives. The history of STILL Forklifts GmbH 

Hans STILL founded the company in Hamburg in 1920. At first his business was repairing electric motors. He fast moved on to manufacturing them. Generators were at first at the heart of the company's portfolio. Post-war, STILL introduced its first electrically-powered forklifts. German, Italian and Japanese railways ordered 100s of STILL forklifts and electric trolleys in the 1950s, allowing STILL to gain in strength. In 1969, the manufacture of electrical machinery was stopped, with the focus now entirely on the manufacture of industrial vehicles, always aiming at innovation for its customers. By the 1970s, the first fully-automated machines were installed on the STILL production line, while employees were offered flexible working hours. STILL GmbH was one of the first in its field to meet California emissions requirements with its products. In the 1980s, STILL introduced the first hybrid drive industrial truck. STILL Germany continued to expand, and in 1989, for instance, bought the French Saxby concern. The fall of the Berlin wall led to expansion into eastern Europe and in the 2000s, a multi-million euro investment programme in new manufacturing facilities. STILL today says it focuses on innovative and intelligent ideas, always with an eye on the environment.

The German company WEILER is based near Nuremberg and is a world leader in the manufacturing of engine and cycle-controlled lathes. It has subsidiaries in the Czech Republic and North America,  giving it a worldwide reach.

World market leaders in precision lathes since 1938

WEILER Werkzeugmaschinen GmbH is a German firm which manufacturers a range of tools and plant, but specializes in the manufacturing of engine and cycle-controlled lathes. It was founded in 1938 in the town of Herzogenaurach, and was bought by an Austrian company in 1990. The 90s saw WEILER expand into Eastern Europe, and by 2006, the firm had founded a North American subsidiary to sell its lathes in new territories. As of 2012, WEILER Werkzeugmaschinen had a workforce of 550 in its major production facilities in Holoubkov and Emskirchen, and claimed to be the market leader in engine lathes across the world. All of the company's operations are focused around Emskirchen, from research and development to production and marketing. However, its American arm, based in Charleston, supplies advice and spare parts to clients across North America. WEILER Werkzeugmaschinen has recently developed an interest in sustainability, and has created engine lathes which consume 85 percent less electricity when on stand-by and marketing innovative e-Tim power monitors for its installations. Its factories are also powered by solar photovoltaics, showcasing the firm's long-term commitment to the environment. WEILER also remains a family-controlled firm, with a focus on customer satisfaction and stability across all operations. It has an in-house training centre for clients, and ensures that specialist technicians can install WEILER equipment on site where it is required.

is one of the leading companies in the world in the fields of surface protection, repair and joining solutions. Also known as CASTOLIN EUTECTIC, the company has been in existence for over 100 years and has a long-standing reputation for quality and expertise.

Website: castolin.com

About CASTOLIN

CASTOLIN was founded by Jean-Pierre Wasserman in the city of Lausanne, Switzerland in 1906. The company pioneered the brazing of cast iron at low temperatures, a process which completely revolutionised the protection and repair of metals. In these early days, CASTOLIN also developed brazing alloys, fluxes and cast-iron repair techniques, gradually developing a reputation for innovation which continues to the present day.

During the forties, EUTECTIC CASTOLIN Ltd. expanded internationally, opening new facilities in New York, London and Milan. The evolvement of CASTOLIN into a truly global corporation continued at a pace and now the company has a presence in over 100 countries, spanning all five continents. CASTOLIN employs in excess of 1500 people worldwide.

In the year 2000, the Wasserman family sold CASTOLIN to private investors and the company became part of the MEC HOLDING group. Five years later, the Messer family became majority shareholders and the group was renamed MESSER WORLD. CASTOLIN remains a vital part of MESSER WORLD and continues to adhere to its long-standing working philosophies of quality, service and technical leadership.

CASTOLIN Product Portfolio

CASTOLIN provides a host of solutions for joining, repair and protection. The CASTOLIN EUTECTIC product portfolio is wide and varied and includes:

  • Brazing consumables and equipment
  • Coating consumables and equipment
  • Welding consumables and equipment
  • Powder wear plates
  • Welded wear plates

Manufactured in-house using the latest technology, the CASTOLIN EUTECTIC Ltd. range of welding equipment includes digitally controlled pulse inverters and standard inverters for TIG and MMA welding.

HANS WEBER Maschinenfabrik GmbH is a firm which specializes in the manufacturing and distribution of high-quality industrial sanding machines. It has a strong focus on efficiency and innovation.

Manufacturing sanding machines for industry for more than 100 years

The German company HANS WEBER Maschinenfabrik GmbH has been manufacturing industrial sanding machines for over a century. Currently, the firm specializes in producing wide-belt sanding machines for the processing of wood and plastics. HANS WEBER is based in the German town of Kronach, but has distribution partners in Belgium, Bosnia, China, Denmark, England, Italy, Croatia, India, Poland, Portugal, Austria, Slovakia, Sweden and many other nations around the world, meaning that its sanding machines are a global presence in workshops and factories across the globe. WEBER Maschinenfabrik has a keen focus on innovation in the sanding and grinding process. It has pioneered techniques such as the CBF sanding process, which has eliminated many of the flaws on materials that remain after they have been sanded. It has also released a range of HANS WEBER Eco Drive sanders, whose motors deliver a high quality sanding product at a very high level of efficiency, saving energy in the process. Other technologies that HANS WEBER Maschinenfabrik Gmbh specializes in include contact free scanning of materials prior to sanding, so that a precision-sanded finish results. The company sells newly manufactured equipment, but also provides a range of used HANS WEBER sanding devices to customers via its website.

Based near Turin, MARIOTTI is a manufacturer of handling equipment, which nowadays focuses on its range of  compact forklift vehicles and has a global sales network.

Global specialists in three wheeled forklift handling vehicles

The Italian firm MARIOTTI specializes in the manufacturing of  electric three wheeled forklift vehicles. The firm has been active in the handling sector since its founding by Vasco Mariotti in 1920. Growth took off after MARIOTTI was purchased by new owners in 1973, and the firm began to develop a range of custom-built lifting devices for modern industrial needs. Along with forklifts, these included equipment such as counter-weighted lift trucks and electric conveyors, but the firm began to focus more closely on smaller counter-weighted forklifts in the 1980s. Since then, MARIOTTI forklifts have established a significant position in the global forklift market, and around 70 percent of the firm's sales now come from abroad, including large amounts in the United States. This expansion has been based around continually innovating to produce nimble, small but powerful lifting vehicles with advanced steering systems to navigate industrial environments. Despite its global success, MARIOTTI still manufactures all of its products at its factory in Grugliasco near Turin. It has a broad technical capacity, producing forklifts in a range of sizes, and has a global distribution network to reach clients across the world. The firm continues to innovate, with a focus on reducing the size of forklift devices, and maintaining power at the same time.

FESTO is a company which specializes in the manufacture of components and systems to be used in the automation of production. The firm also sells e-learning and workplace design software that links in with its automation products.

World leaders in automation systems and e-learning technology

FESTO AG & Co. KG specialize in the development and manufacturing of automation systems for a wide range of industrial settings. Founded in 1925, FESTO now has more than 16,000 employees across the world, a presence in 61 countries and more than 250 branch offices. In addition to its country offices, FESTO can also offer after sales service in almost any location, providing a full suite of training and consultancy services to ensure that clients receive the right automation solution to their industrial challenges. At the heart of the company's expansion has been a commitment to innovation, and 7 percent of the firm's annual revenues are ploughed back into research and development. This means that the firm generates over 100 unique patents every year, and has accumulated 2,900 patents across the world, allowing the firm to stay ahead of the services offered by its competitors.

Investing in human capital and pushing technology forwards

Some of the technologies pioneered by FESTO include biomechanics, which studies how natural forms can be applied to automated production systems. The firm's "SupraMotion" systems are also looking into means of applying contactless production techniques using hovering objects, while IT technology is applied at every stage of the automation processes delivered by FESTO. Along with the corporate focus on research and development, the company has also invested heavily in ensuring that its workforce is well educated, and each employee can benefit from courses laid on by the firm to enhance their productivity and skills. This is coupled with FESTO Didactic, the arm of the company which works with educational institutions and laboratories to design high-technology learning environments. This has ensured that FESTO has become the world's leading supplier of industrial education products, including areas like pneumatics, robotics, electrohydraulics and CNC technology.

Global suppliers of advanced machine tools since 1894

Gebr. HELLER Maschinenfabrik GmbH is one of the leading German manufacturers of machine tools, with a focus on milling machinery. The company was founded in 1894 by Hermann Heller as a supplier of tools to the watch-making trade. The firm soon branched out into supplying a variety of products, such as chimney heads and emergency steel escape stairs, before finding its speciality with the manufacturing of machine tools in the 1900s. The portable oscillating saws manufactured by HELLER Group became indispensable to Swabian railway companies during the 1910s, but by 1925 the firm had expanded to sell its tools across Germany and Europe. These included some technologically advanced milling tools which, even by 1930 had incorporated hydraulic components, and HELLER was also a pioneer in the use of modular production lines.

Focusing on the customer and ensuring that tools are maintained efficiently

EISENMANN Germany is one of the world's leading manufacturers of paint application systems, biogas plants and thermal processing systems. Its products are particularly associated with the automobile industry.

Experts in the production of paint shops, thermal processes and renewable energy

EISENMANN AG is a German firm which specializes in plant engineering, which includes the delivery of surface finishing technologies, automation of material flows, high temperature systems and environmental technologies. EISENMANN SE was founded by Eugen Eisenmann in 1951 and now employs almost 4,000 people around the world. Its origins lie in wood processing kilns, which were in high demand in post-war Germany as construction expanded. By 1953, EISENMANN SE had expanded into manufacturing paint shops, introducing innovative new conveyor belt painting systems in the 1960s, as well as the first electro-dip paint coating plant in 1966. The 1970s saw these painting processes being adapted for the growing automobile industry, and by 1980, almost all major European car manufacturers had invested in EISENMANN products to ensure that their products received a high quality surface finish. This was also a period of technological change, as the firm introduced powerful computer-based control systems for its equipment and introduced electrified monorail production lines as well.

Constantly innovating to develop new plant installations

The 1980s saw no slowing of this innovation. During this decade, EISENMANN AG expanded its environmental technologies business, creating new ways of converting waste into energy via its range of thermal oxidisers. In 1986, the firm also introduced a world first with its high pressure paint stripping facility, and also introduced efficient new enamelling systems for household goods. In the 90s, the firm penetrated the ceramics industry, with its range of high-temperature kilns, and it also pioneered new methods of paint recycling. This was also a period of rapid international expansion, with EISENMANN Corp opening plants in Mexico, Thailand, Russia, South Korea and Argentina, amongst other places. This was accompanied in the 2000s with new facilities like the firm's global training centre, as well as revolutionary new technologies in the growing biogas sector. However, the company remains anchored in tradition, and the community in the town of Böblingen, despite being a global player. Around 60 percent of its workers are based in Europe, with the rest operating in emerging markets across the globe. Despite being a global company, EISENNMANN remains a family-run firm, with the executive board being supervised by Peter EISENMANN.

The EISENMANN product portfolio

The range of products manufactured by EISENMANN includes:

  • Paint shops
  • Body shop conveyor lines for automobile production
  • Production control systems
  • High temperature processes (coil coating, carbon fiber and surface finishing)
  • Robotic paint appliers
  • Cleaning systems
  • Sealing applications
  • Electrified monorail systems
  • Floor-based conveyor systems
  • Exhaust air treatment machinery
  • Waste water treatment
  • Weapons destruction machinery
  • Biogas plants
  • Software for use with EISENMANN products

The plant installations manufactured by EISENMANN are used in many economic sectors. Their paint shops are commonly used by vehicle manufacturers, and their thermal processing technology is used in the production of household goods. Their biogas technologies are increasingly used in the production of energy by public bodies.

The Chinese company EUREKA specializes in exporting printing and paper cutting, folding and processing machinery for use in the high-end publishing sector, amongst other settings.
